title: FIH Nations Cup: Why Savita Punia and Coâ€™s win in Spain was an important feat for Indian hockey
content:
As the final hooter went, the joy on the faces of the Indian players was unmistakeable. The players on the sidelines hugged coach Janneke Schopman. Intense as ever from the sidelines when the match was unfolding, she finally let her guard down. The former Olympic and World Champion was beaming, her face a mixture of happiness as well as relief as she asked the players to go and celebrate with their teammates first.You didnâ€™t need words to describe how the players and staff were feeling. The delight was self-evident in the 50 second-video below, as Savita Punia and Co won the first edition of the FIH Hockey Womenâ€™s Nations Cup Spain 2022.â€œAh, itâ€™s amazing. I canâ€™t explain in words, lots of emotions. This win is very big for us, we have worked very hard for a long time for this,â€ captain and goalkeeper of the tournament Punia told FIH shortly after, still dealing with the emotions of a close win against hosts Spain, the team ranked one place above India.That winning feeling for @thehockeyindia ğŸ˜ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡³Inside Indiaâ€™s bench for those final seconds and then the on-pitch celebrations ğŸ™Œ #Pitchside Watch all the highlights on the @watchdothockey app ğŸ“² pic.twitter.com/VQjWWTviTZâ€” International Hockey Federation (@FIH_Hockey) December 17, 2022

Of course, winning an event â€“ any international event, really â€“ is an achievement worth celebrating but the importance of the Nations Cup triumph for the Indian women went beyond just beating Spain in their backyard and standing on top of the podium. It meant the Indian women have earned the right to be part of the FIH Pro League in 2023-â€™24.â€œIt just felt really good, it was a goal we had set ourselves as a team that we had to win this tournament and qualify for Pro League,â€ Navneet Kaur, arguably Indiaâ€™s best outfield player in recent months, told Scroll.in on her return from Spain.â€œWe worked so hard in our camp, almost 40 days and most of that time were red sessions, the hardest intensity. It wasnâ€™t just five matches, we also had practice matches in Spain so it was a total of nine matches. By the end we were all quite tired. But we also remembered our aim and the happiest feeling was realising we achieved the target we set out to, proud of the fact that we won what we dreamed of winning.â€A brief backgroundSo why are the Indian women not playing in the ongoing Pro League season in the first place? Punia and Co featured in the 2021-â€™22 season and finished third on their debut campaign, earning some impressive wins and putting some good performances along the way against Spain, eventual champions Argentina, and even defeating the Netherlands (albeit a second string side). But India were only in the league as replacement for one of the original set of teams in the league, with Australia and New Zealand pulling out of last season due to Covid-related restrictions. So once they returned for the current season, India missed out. As for why Indian women were not part of the league originally... well, thatâ€™s a long story. And one, ironically, had a basis in the belief that the womenâ€™s team (a few years back) were not good enough to finish in the top four of this tournament and hence their efforts would be better focussed elsewhere in search of a spot at the Olympics. Indeed, both the Indian menâ€™s and womenâ€™s team didnâ€™t feature in the opening edition when there was still a question mark over how relevant the league was going to be in the calendar. But the men were included from the second edition onward as a spot opened up while the women were not that fortunate. The importance of Pro League, then, was evident in the Indian menâ€™s run to the bronze medal in Tokyo. Even players spoke about what the tournament offered, in terms of competing with the top teams in the world more regularly, and not just in context-less bilateral Test series. The women didnâ€™t have that luxury in the lead up to Tokyo.With another big year coming up which includes the prospects of the Asian Games and Olympic qualification, the Indian women would be forced to face another few months ahead of them with limited game time. They would be dependent on arranging bilateral tours (an upcoming visit to South Africa and then one to Australia later on are on the cards). But the triumph in Valencia, where they won five out of five, has ensured that in the lead up to Paris 2024, the Indian womenâ€™s team will rub shoulders with the best teams in the world... and on merit as the Nations Cup introduces promotion-relegation. â€œThe way we performed last year (in the Pro League), we deserved to play against the best teams in the world,â€ midfielder Sonika told Scroll.in. â€œFor us it was important (to win) because earlier weâ€™d only get to play against teams like Argentina and the Netherlands at major tournaments. But now weâ€™re getting those chances so it was important to win this.â€œThis was the first time we won a medal outside an Asian country, playing against a European country. That was a proud thing for us. Last year we played as a replacement  for another team in the Pro League. Now when we go, uska ek alag he maza hai (it will hit different).â€Navneet Kaur, too, echoed that sentiment. â€œWhen we played Pro League last season we experienced that we play the  best teams in the world, there is a special level of confidence you gain  from that,â€ Navneet said. â€œIt really helped us, when we played  Commonwealth Games and even World Cup to know our level. For 2024  Olympics preparation, we will have Pro League matches.â€  Living up to favourites tagAt Tokyo Olympics, the Indian womenâ€™s hockey team provided plenty of joy to fans of the sport even if they finished a heartbreaking fourth. Indeed, there are few things more cruel than finishing in that position that puts you so close to the podium and yet feels so far off. But the defeat, and the closeness of it in the bronze medal playoff ,was a virtual starting point for the women, not a destination. It put them on the map of world womenâ€™s hockey, teams started noticing them more and studied their style. It also brought with it more expectations from fans in India. Most of all, it made the players expect more from themselves, even if that meant adding more pressure.In the World Cup this year, one could see that the team was perhaps still coming to terms with that. Savita Punia had said before the tournament that the team was very much aware of the hopes that were being placed on them now, but it got to them at the marquee event. It was also a lesson in dealing with the said pressure.â€œWe learned from the World Cup, the decision-making aspect. We canâ€™t say â€˜donâ€™t take pressureâ€™ but it is there at this level,â€ Navneet Kaur said. â€œHow we deal with it, that is important.  What we learned from losses that is important. Our team is slowly learning how to maintain our quality as we keep improving, because earlier our level wasnâ€™t this high. Now expectations are there, that too is pressure and we are learning well how to deal with it and focus on our game. Thatâ€™s I think why our performances were good.â€ India (W) at FIH Nations Cup 2022

  While the long term objective of returning to Pro League was important, in the short term it was crucial for the team to win a tournament where they entered as one of the favourites. That they can win not just as underdogs, but also thrive as a team with a target on the back. To borrow a couple of phrases from Schopmanâ€™s recent Scroll.in interview, it was validation that this team is doing a lot of things right and must realise at times how good they actually are.â€œWe trained knowing that we have to take it one match at a time, not look far ahead,â€ Navneet said, of the time since the CWG 2022 bronze and Nations Cup. â€œWe also looked at the videos of all the teams that we were playing, and what their strengths were. We knew our speed is good, our 1-to-1 hockey is good, how to use that. Our coach told us that it was important to take right decisions with the ball, it was all about mindset. Hockey wise we know what to do, but dealing with the pressure and taking decisions under pressure... that was really good from us this tournament and thatâ€™s why we won.â€Indeed so, in the short term as well as the long term, the FIH Nations Cup triumph for Savita Punia and Co is a definite shot in the arm.
